title: How the US and Saudi Arabia could respond to attacks on Saudi oil fields, and why the Saudis are still vulnerable
text:
What does this mean for the United States' strategy in its confrontation with Iran?

Iranian President Hassan Rouhani, right, and Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif at a meeting with Muslim leaders and scholars in Hyderabad, India, February 15, 2018. Reuters

The United States remains committed to a sanctions-first strategy in dealing with Iran as Washington tries to force Tehran to abandon ts ballistic missile and nuclear programs and its support for proxy forces across the Middle East.

In a September 18 tweet, US President Donald Trump hinted at a "substantial" increase in sanctions on Iran within 48 hours, and the State Department has repeatedly reiterated that sanctions are the primary US tool to try to alter Iranian behavior. On September 20, the US Treasury announced new sanctions on Iran's central bank.

Trump has displayed a clear reticence to striking Iran militarily in the run-up to the 2020 US presidential election, preferring more muted actions such as cyberattacks and additional sanctions.

While less likely, the United States might assess that military retaliation is necessary to punish Iran and deter against future attacks. Washington is also considering joint operations with Saudi Arabia in which the Saudis would lead retaliatory actions against Iran aided by US intelligence, targeting and surveillance.
description: Attacks on Saudi oil facilities earlier this month revealed the shortcomings of Saudi defenses for the country's oil production.
